prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not allowing my gf (28) to be friends with co-worker(of 3+ years) anymore for calling one of their co-workers her "boyfriend"?
A little background, me and my gf live together (3 Months now) but have been on and off for 4 years. She's been friends with this girl for 3+ years. My gf told me straight up that this guy (let's call him Sam from now on) Sam doesn't talk too anyone at their job (plenty of male female associates). But, since he has worked there he "waves" at my gf and is the only person at their job he kinda talks to. I was ok with that. I trusted her since she brought it up. 

I posted yesterday that we go through each other's phones. Well she deleted a few message. Most were innocent "what are you girls wearing tomorrow?". How I know you ask? Well she has a Fitbit and while she deletes her text on her phone her Fitbit takes longer to delete them. (this isn't the point of this post please don't focus or make your decision based off this). But I used the knowledge that she erased messages (she doesn't know her fitbit is betraying her) to let her tell me everything she deleted. Turns out that she deleted a message where her friend said something along the lines of "your boyfriend (Sam) was late to work last night" my gf told me that she ignored the message and moved the conversation on. I believe her because she is under the impression that I read it all (still thinks I hacked her phone when in reality she sank herself. I read one fitbit message).

After finding this out. I said "I don't want you to be friends with her anymore she doesn't respect me as your man and us as a couple". I know some people joke around and sometimes have innocent "work husband's". I'm not ok with either. I believe my gf should had told her friend that it's not ok to call another man that and I don't think her friend had a right to joke like that. 

Am I the asshole for not wanting her to keep that friend anymore? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the main issue is that the author's girlfriend has a friend who called a male coworker her "boyfriend." The author found out through some deleted messages that the friend had referred to the coworker that way and then decided the girlfriend shouldn't be friends with her anymore.

First, I need to consider the context. The girlfriend and the coworker (Sam) have been coworkers for three years. The author was okay with Sam being the only person he interacted with at work. The problem arises when the friend refers to Sam as the "boyfriend." The author feels that this is disrespectful and doesn't want the friendship to continue.

Now, the key points here: the friend's statement was likely a joke or a work-related term, common in some workplaces where people refer to each other as "boyfriend" or "girlfriend" for convenience. The author's reaction is to cut off the friendship because of this. The girlfriend didn't confront the friend about it, which the author seems to take as her not standing up for the relationship.

But wait, the author found out through deleted messages. The friend's message was a casual work joke, and the girlfriend didn't respond to it. The author is taking a strict stance against any reference to work relationships, even if they're not real. Is that reasonable? Maybe the author is overreacting, thinking that a joke at work is a personal slight. Also, cutting off a friend just because someone joked about a coworker being their "boyfriend" might be too harsh. The friend might not have meant anything by it, and the girlfriend's friend might not realize it's an issue.

On the other hand, the author might feel that such terms are inappropriate, especially in a relationship. The act of deleting messages could also be a red flag for the author, making him more sensitive to any perceived betrayal. However, the friend's comment was a one-time joke, and the author's reaction is to end the friendship entirely. That seems extreme.

The author is the one who decided to end the friendship without discussing it with the girlfriend first. The girlfriend might not agree with that decision, especially if she values the friendship and thinks the comment was harmless. The author's trust in the girlfriend was initially there, but now he's questioning that trust based on a single joke. 

So, is the author right to cut off the friend? It depends on the relationship dynamics and how both parties view boundaries. If the couple had discussed boundaries beforehand, maybe the author would have a point. But since the friend's comment was a work joke, and the girlfriend didn't engage with it, the author's reaction might be overstepping. The friend didn't do anything to harm the relationship, so ending the friendship seems like a harsh measure.
